module.p: le with, by is the (non-leniting) instrumental preposition.

section.p:
The default form of the instrumental preposition is simply le –
le taigh with a house
le aislingean with dreams
le Nirribhidh with Norway
le trì làithean with three days

When the immediately following word is a form of the definite article, the linking form leis is used –
leis an taigh with the house
leis a’ bhaile with the town
leis na h-aislingean with the dreams

Fused forms are occasionally found when the immediately following word is a possessive determiner –
le mo thaigh with my house ≈ lem thaigh
le do bhaile with your town ≈ led bhaile
le a h-eaglais with her church ≈ le h-eaglais
le a chraoibh with his tree ≈ le chraoibh
le ar n-achadh with our field
le ur leapannan with your beds
le an taighean with their houses ≈ len taighean
le am baile with their town ≈ lem baile
Note that these fused forms are rather awkward and hence are best avoided in writing nowadays.

Conjugated prepositions are used in place of le mi, le thu, ... , le iad –
leam with me
leat with you
leatha with her/it
leis with him/it
leinn with us
leibh with you
leotha with them

There are also emphatic forms (cf. le mise, le thusa, ... , le iadsan) –
leamsa with me
leatsa with you
leathase with her/it
leis-san with him/it
leinne with us
leibhse with you
leothasan with them
Note that the form leathase breaks the ‘slender-to-slender, broad-to-broad’ spelling rule, and hence is sometimes found written with a hyphen – leatha-se.

Finally, there are also reflexive forms (cf. le mi fhìn, le thu fhèin, ... , le iad fhèin) –
leam fhèin / fhìn with myself
leat fhèin with yourself
leatha fhèin with herself/itself
leis fhèin with himself/itself
leinn fhèin / fhìn with ourselves
leibh fhèin with yourself
leotha fhèin with themselves

Some examples –
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” [...]
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” [...] td. 5
Bha an latha brèagha blàth is thug an athair leis Iain agus Anna anns a’ chàr.
The day was lovely and warm and their father took John and Ann in the car. td. 6

le can be used to introduce the complement of a verb –
rach le go with something, take something
thoir leam take/bring something
na stad le bhith a’ dèanamh rud not stop at doing something, go beyond doing something

le can be used to introduce the modifier of a verb –
ruith le run with something

Examples from Gairm –
[...] ’Se madainn bhòidheach foghair a bh’ ann—tioram, le ceileir eòin, is beagan dealt air an fheur. Bha a[m] muir ’s na tighean ag éirigh á inntinn an latha. [...]
[...] It was a beautiful autumn morning – dry, with the chirping of birds, and a little dew on the grass. The sea and the houses were rising from the mind of the day [??]. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
